IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: Our mission is opening doors to bright futures for kids. During the past year alone, our programs reached over 4,800 children in low-income or at-risk families, working to meet their immediate needs and helping those around them to create healthy environments at home, in child care and school, and in the community. CYFS programs serve Charlottesville and five surrounding counties (Albemarle, Fluvanna, Greene, Louisa, and Nelson), and address the issues of poverty, abuse and neglect, parenting, child care quality, teen runaways, and early learning, including social and pre-literacy skills. The theme shared by all of our programs is that they are all about kids - about reaching children wherever they are - at home, in child care, in school, or on the streets - and giving them the chance to reach their full potential.
IRS990.MissionDescription: Our Mission is opening doors to bright futures for kids. During the past year alone, our programs reached over 4800 children in low-income or at-risk families, working to meet their immediate needs and helping those around them to create healthy environments at home, in child care and school, and in the community. CYFS programs serve Charlottesville and five surrounding counties (Albemarle, Fluvanna, Greene, Louisa, and Nelson), and address the issues of poverty, abuse and neglect, parenting, child care quality, teen runaways, and early learning, including social and pre-literacy skills. The theme shared by all of our programs is that they are all about kids - about reaching children wherever they are - at home, in child care, in school, or on the streets - and giving them the chance to reach their full potential.
IRS990.Description: Home Visiting: Professional home visitors work with parents of at-risk babies and young children to help them create a healthy, nurturing environment. The Home Visiting program began providing mental health services to at-risk mothers who are struggling with symptoms of depression. This is a vital component to promoting the positive development of their children. In the past year, Home Visitors made 893 home visits with 76 families and 82 children.

Activity2.Description: Child Care Quality: Staff provides advice and help for parents seeking quality child care in the Charlottesville area, and training and support to child care providers to improve the quality of care they give. CCQ Educators piloted the state's new Star Quality Rating System and were some of the first staff to be qualified as raters and mentors. The program was also awarded two new state grants to increase regional training for quality care for infants and toddlers. Last year 2,000 children in child care were positively affected by this program people were served directly by this program. The program referred 258 families to child care providers and provided rating and training to 255 child care centers.

Activity3.Description: Runaway Emergency Services Program (RESP): RESP provides a 24-hour hotline for kids in crisis and free emergency shelter in volunteer homes for kids who have run away or are homeless. Since adding a new full-time counselor at the beginning of the year, the CYFS Runaway Emergency Services Program (RESP) outreach activities have doubled in scope and more than doubled in numbers of youth reached through face-to-face contact. As a result, preventative counseling cases have also more than doubled, keeping at-risk youth off the streets and helping them work through family issues before they resort to dangerous behaviors. Last year, 131 teens called our hotline, 53 received counseling, and 14 were given emergency shelter. Over 580 teens made direct, face-to-face contact during outreach events.

ActivityOther.Description: 1. Victims of Child Abuse (VOCA): VOCA provides free professional counseling to children and adolescents who are victims of child abuse or neglect, as well as to non-abusing family members, to heal the trauma of the abuse and create safe and nurturing home environments. The program provided counseling services to 92 child victims and 70 family members. Our Victims of Child Abuse (VOCA) program was awarded two highly competitive state grants that have allowed us to hire two additional full-time counselors and several part-time counselors. This expansion allowed us to provide counseling services on-site in the outlying counties and greatly reduces our waiting list for services. 2. Early Learning: STAR Kids and Play Partners send staff and volunteers to teach low-income preschoolers pre-reading and social skills. Also during the past year our Play Partners early literacy program was purchased for implementation in a community in South Carolina and was publically recognized by the national organization, Child Care Continuum, as a model program. This year, these two programs served 459 children. 3. Family Connections: Family Connections offers parenting classes, specialized workshops and home consultations to families of young children, families of teenagers, and families torn by divorce or violence. Over 826 parents and children were served this year. Our ParentingMobile, a bright green van that travels to at-risk neighborhoods, increased service to twice weekly to the Southwood community, a primarily Latino low-income neighborhood. The Junior League partnered with the program to offer developmental playgroups and literacy activities for young children and a partnership with local food co-ops provided free, fresh, healthy food for 420 families.

ProgramServiceRevenue.Description: FEES COLLECTED FOR TRAINING, CONSULTING, AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The board-designated quasi-endowment funds are designated by the Board of Directors to be used for long-term growth of the Agency and to address potential short-term budget short-falls.
Direct fundraising expenses for fundraising events.
Direct fundraising expenses for fundraising events.

Form990ScheduleLPartIV.Relationship: FAMILY MEMBER OF CURRENT EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Form 990 was presented to the board's Finance Committee prior to submission. The committee had the opportunity to review the completed form with the Finance Manager and Executive Director and provide any feedback regarding its contents. Suggested edits were incorporated prior to the document being presented to the Board of Directors and filed with the IRS.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Board's by-laws specifically outline the board's conflict of interest policy. The policy is reviewed with board members during orientation and each board member signs a written contract, which includes their commitment to following the written policy. During board meetings and as issues arise, board members are asked about potential conflicts of interest and board members voluntarily recuse themselves from decision-making.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: All compensation is reviewed through multiple means. First, the board's Personnel Committee conducts a salary and benefits survey every two years to compare agency salary and benefits with other local nonprofits and government agencies. Second, the Personnel Committee recommends and the board approves all cost of living increases. Finally, the Personnel Committee annually reviews the agency's salary classification levels, which sets the compensation range for each level of position in the agency. The Executive Director's compensation is reviewed and determined by the full board upon hire and with any subsequent salary adjustments.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: All governing documents, including our conflict of interest policy, and financial statements are maintained in a file at the CYFS' offices and are available upon request. Financial statements are included within our annual report. Our annual report is mailed to 4,000 community members and our audit, Form 990, and annual report are posted on our website, which is available to the general public.

NEPOTISM POLICY Children, Youth & Family Services, Inc. is an equal opportunity employer and hires individuals solely based on their qualifications and ability to do the job to be filled. CYFS will consider a member of an employee's immediate family or a director's immediate family for employment if the applicant possesses all the qualifications for employment. An immediate family member may not be hired, however, if the employment would: (a) Create either a direct supervisor/subordinate relationship with a family member; or (b) Create an actual conflict of interest or the appearance of a conflict of interest. These criteria will also be considered when assigning, transferring, or promoting an employee. In no case may related employees have any influence over the wages, hours, benefits, career progress and other terms and conditions of the other related staff members. For purposes of this policy, "immediate family" includes: the employee or director's spouse, brother, sister, mother, father, stepmother, stepfather, children, stepchildren, father-in-law, mother-in-law, sister-in-law, brother-in-law, daughter-in-law, son-in-law, and any other member of the employee or director's household. Employees who marry or become members of the same household may continue employment as long as there is not: (a) A direct supervisor/subordinate relationship between the employees; or (b) An actual conflict of interest or the appearance of a conflict of interest. Should one of the above situations occur, CYFS will attempt to find a suitable position within the agency to which one of the employees may transfer. If accommodations of this nature are not feasible, the employees will first be permitted to determine which of them will resign. If no agreement between the employees can be reached, CYFS will decide which of the employees will be terminated. If the family member is within the chain of command but not within the direct supervision of the family member, the following shall apply: Performance evaluations, hiring decisions, and compensation decisions will skip the family member and be reviewed and signed by the next supervisor in the chain of command. If the Executive Director is the family member, the performance evaluation will be reviewed and signed by the Board President. The direct supervisor and employee shall both have access to the Chair of the Personnel Committee for consultation and assistance should performance issues or grievances arise. If the family member is related to a member of the Board, the following shall apply: Performance evaluations, hiring decisions, and compensation decisions will be reviewed and signed by the Board President. The related employee and his/her direct supervisor shall have access to the Chair of the Personnel Committee should performance issues or grievances arise.
